author: Telegraph reporter
title: Would-be thief tried using magnet to steal from coin-pushing machines on Brighton Pier
text: A man who took a 'large magnet' with him to a popular seaside pier in an attempt to pull 10p coins towards him from an arcade machine has been fined the equivalent of 3450 10p pieces. Suspicions were aroused when Vladimir Ivanov, 35, acted strangely in front of the coin pushing machine and police were called. Security detained him until officers arrived and discovered a large magnet in Ivanov's possession - and he was unable to explain why he had it. But he was convicted of going equipped for theft at one of Britain's most popular amusement arcades on Brighton Pier, East Sussex. Magistrates in Brighton ordered for the magnet to be destroyed and Ivanov, speaking through a Russian translator, admitted the charge which saw him fined £110 - and facing costs of £235. Magnetic putty swallows up magnet in mesmerising timelapse Willy Wonka-style elevator uses magnets to move sideways Sussex Police said they have never heard of anything similar to what Ivanov, of Burgess Hill, West Sussex, was apparently trying to do on April 20. John Whittaker, of Whittaker Bros who are leading manufacturer in coin operated amusement machines, said it would be almost impossible to extract coins using a magnet. He said: "I have not heard of that happening before. "I would have thought you would need such a strong magnet because you are so far away from the coins anyway, unless they are dropping a string with a magnet on down through the coin slots or something like that. "Obviously people do fish with bits of string with various things on, but there are measures to stop that. "There is also a mechanical switch which has to operate [to let the coins through] - so I don't think it would be easy at all."
